comments.commentBody: This is why there were discrepancies based on education.  Many people who have lower education levels do more physically demanding work, and therefore are not physically able to work as long as folks with more education and less physical jobs.  And this is why we must not raise the minimum retirement age above 62.  But the problem remains that this system keeps people in lower socioeconomic brackets.  They are often forced by economic reality to start collecting Social Security benefits earlier than those whose jobs and not so wearing, and therefore their checks are smaller resulting in more proscribed lifestyles.  They are often the same demographic that has not been able to save much for retirement and have no pensions either.

To paraphrase Chief Justice Roberts, "It's a sordid business, this divvying us up by gender." Soon we will have endless discussions about the possibly first female president, and millions of people will vote for a woman because she is a woman, or against her because she is a woman. Pick the best person, and stop worrying about how nice it would be to have a black, woman, Hispanic, Jew, Christian, gay, transgender, or some other category in a position!

Joel, I don't think the need to protect the president so well is ridiculous. Given his position and power, and the fact that he wouldn't last a day without security, it's necessary. Lax security gets presidents assassinated.

As for succession, I for one do not want Joe Biden to be president. Nor do I want Rep. Boehner. I don't know how one would require that successors be competent, and who would decide that. Ostensibly, voters do that as part of the process.
There is no major versus minor distinction regarding the Roosevelts.
He essentially gave her a pass, Miriam. His criticism was of the Secret Service over the years, not her. Nothing in his post was a gender-based swipe.

Although I can find nothing in Ms. Pierson's Wikipedia biography that would seem to justify her elevation to the leadership of a major federal agency, it is not likely that any incompetence on her part was responsible for the lapses in performance of the Secret Service. It is very curious that an agency with a reputation for heroism and competence approaching that of the FBI, should have had so few successes in preventing lethal attacks on our presidents. Since Lincoln's assassination, Presidents Garfield, McKinley, Roosevelt major, Roosevelt minor, Kennedy, Ford, and Reagan were all shot at with no interference from the SS. The cases of Ford and Reagan are particularly notable. During a period of less than three weeks Gerald Ford was attacked, first by Squeaky Frome and then by Sara Jane Moore. Frome flred from point blank range but the weapon failed to go off because she had not properly loaded it. Moore missed but not by much. In 1981 Reagan was allowed to walk 30 feet from the rear entrance of the Washington Hilton to his limousine past a rope line of unvetted well-wishers, including John Hinckley. Hinckley was able to fire six shots before being subdued by a civilian. To summarize, not a single determined attack has been prevented by the SS.
Let us not, however, ignore the successes. No American is allowed to drive past the White House grounds on Pennsylvania Avenue. Also, each time the president visits a major city, its traffic is reduced to gridlock.

Exactly. Thank you. It's not one of the richest, it's the richest (and last rentier) pie out there. This is so obvious and hardly ever mentioned in discussions of privatization. The bankers want their piece. They're never going to stop harping. The stakes are too big.

The Republican alternative to Social Security is mandatory individual retirement savings managed by the private investment banking industry at retail rates. Makes me feel warm and financially secure just typing it!
Exactly!
Absolutely, privatize it to their wealthy "buddies", no safety anymore.

"[Social Security's] administrative costs are well below 1 percent of expenditures. 'It’s much more efficient than private sector retirement programs,' said Jason Furman, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, in a phone interview."

That's exactly why conservative politicians want to convert it to a privatized system, so their Wall Street benefactors and cohorts can tap into one of the richest untapped rentier pies out there. It's not ideological at all; it's looting, plain and simple.

"there is always a scapegoat and there is a female "in charge", the scapegoat is ready-made for public flogging."  Frankly speaking this is both sexist and ridiculous.  Incompetence is not limited to one gender.  Ms Pierson was out of her depth and was well separated from her employment.  As she would have been were she somehow Mr. Pierson.
Just like the retiring members of our incompetent and obstructionist congress.
Notwithstanding her resignation, she will likely collect a large government pension, after working for the govt. for so many years. Just sayin'...
She should have announced her resignation at the hearing. The public would have applauded her accepting responsibility. Now it seems as if she is slinking away.

D. Annie -
I have to agree with you that it is likely there is an animus among the mostly male Secret Service against this woman, who is also reform-minded and willing to terminate a number of their jobs. I'm not a conspiracy nut but it seems very odd that these things happened on her watch and I wonder if her poor judgment was related to advice/comments she heard from men in her office.

In short...you get what you pay for.  My son is attending a private school, which is costing us a little more than what our flagship state university would, after the college's grants are added in.  In the meantime he's getting smaller class sizes, often superior faciliies and actually made it on to one of his school's sports teams.  We are not poor, but as some other contributors noted, the free money offered by some private colleges do make them an affordable option and, in my estimation, a superior value to state schools with lower sticker prices.

Value added taxes hit hardest on those least able to pay, as do sales taxes.  As for reducing tax expenditures, I could agree if the first place we started was cutting the subsidies to those best able to afford the cuts - like the oil industry and agriculture.  For examine, the family of Representative Tom Cotton of Arkansas has received hundreds of thousands of dollars in farm subsidies.  Cotton is presently saying in his political ads that he voted against the Farm Bill because it  included food stamps (which has been the case since 1973).   Of course, he first voted for the Farm subsidy bill when the House tried to separate food stamps from the farm subsidy bill - after all, his family should continue to receive subsidies while food assistance for poor families should be cut.

Social Security benefits don't have to change but the job killing payroll taxes need to go. Bill Gates said that taxing jobs is no way to create jobs and over taxing workers is no way to increase economic demand. A value added tax, wealth tax and/or reduction in tax expenditures is the best way to end stagnation and restore opportunity.

"she was against the wall with no other way out."

I don't see that. It wouldn't explain why she couldn't have told the president about the incident regarding the man in the elevator when she had the opportunity last week. The people under her report(ed) to HER. She couldn't have made herselflook WORSE than she did by withholding the information.
If something like this exists, it's time to raise income tax on the top 5%. That, or  patiently await the revolution.
Kids should be inventing their own games, being creative by themselves, not under the tutelage of adults who structure their "play" time the same way school is structured.
This seems to be aimed at parents who do CrossFit and who want to brag that their children do it too, even though it might be totally inappropriate for young children.
those with very large incomes want more hence the other goodies in our tax code and the issue of the '47%'

NYT has reported in the past that kids aren't getting as much recess at school as they used to. Some don't get any. Also, Kindergartners don't play, they sit. Many places have cut PE altogether, or have large classes in small spaces.
How about that they get these devices vetted for saftety, efficacy, and usability by the FDA during the time out?

The EHR has become an emerging disease, requiring more intellectual power to manage than does the patients' diseases.

The most diseased component is the electronic ordering device. This represents a formidable impediment to safe and efficient care.

I don't believe this is accurate. My records have been transferred between hospitals and doctors in 2 different systems without me being present...with no problems. While the connectivity in the US is not perfect I don't believe this is one of problems.

That is crazy. If you're an M.D. and can't master EPIC, clunky as it is, I suggest you're in the wrong profession. EPIC will be replaced eventually but probably no one, including Mark, pushed for efficient, transferable records. Shame on all of us for allowing this...

I agree. Many of the writers here are eager to blame the only company that came forward to at least attempt medical record connectivity...the medical community has only itself to blame. But I would disagree about ALL's comment about the Obamacare web site. Remember the conservative Congress actually refused to vote funds to make the system work...and to educate the public...and to this day continues to denigrate it. It's truly amazing it works at all.

A mechanic's lien is most often released during a bankruptcy
.
Public employee's pay is now not less than private sector ... so their pensions should also be similar.   Have and eat your cake doesnt work.

Detroit is a perfect example of corruption within it's pension system. For decades pension money was handed out to people that were never entitled to it. The last estimate was nearly 1 billion dollars tossed out the window. Everyone knows public sector worker unions demand and get higher pensions than can be paid for but yet they still demand them. It's time for change and realize we are no longer a rich nation.

It seems to me like the municipalities got the labor, not fully compensated at the time but with a promise to pay in the future, and now are possibly going to be allowed to default on their obligations. That is now pinches cities to pay is too bad, but it pinched to work for less than those in the private sector, relying on the cities to eventually make good, however partially, the differentials in pay. Mechanics have leans on houses for work done, first liens that are a security interest in the property title that benefits those who have did the work or supplied materials. Public service workers (you know, teachers, police, fire fighters) should have first claim on city assets (you know, art museums, park land, etc.) when cities go belly up.

As soon as your medical records are exposed on electronic systems you have lost your right to confidentiality. Your data can be accessed by an ever-widening variety of eyes.
Use faxes or, yes, walk the data over as before.

Mergers of hospitals with incompatible electronic record systems can really create record-sharing problems.   I recently underwent a series of medical tests and discovered that, although all of my doctors have Mt. Sinai Hospital/NYC privileges or are attending specialists there, they could not all share my test results with each other. Mt Sinai Hospital bought Roosevelt Hospital and St. Luke's Hospital from Columbia in Sept 2013.  In Jan 2014, the hospitals merged.  It is now October 2014 and no common electronic record system is in place.  I had to ask for film copies of my tests and then hand delivered them to my doctors who use one system so they could see the tests recorded on the other system.  If I had known this in advance, I would have endeavored to find doctors who all used the same electronic record system!

Please! Anyone familiar with the healthcare IT industry knows Faulkner is engaging in the worst kind of revisionist history. Her real views and anti-interoperability scare tactics are on record in a 2009 Bloomberg interview. Her words then: "It doesn't work when you mix and match vendors," and "It has to be one system, or it can be dangerous for patients."
Care Everywhere came about because Epic couldn't scale its large, multi-site Kaiser implementation and had to get creative about how to connect the various hospitals and clinics. It was and is for connecting one Epic site to another Epic site. It is NOT for true vendor to vendor interoperability. Epic customers who want real interoperability are on their own to pursue it, often paying others to do the hard work because Epic can't be bothered to do anything extra to make it work.
Sarcasm/Irony? At its best! Go Bob!

"And Social Security is a terrific program... 'It’s much more efficient than private sector retirement programs,' said Jason Furman, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, in a phone interview.

Gail, are you being deliberately provocative? The mere mention that a government-run program might be both good and more cost effective than comparable private sector options is just one step away from telling Congressional Republicans that the earth orbits the sun. Sorry GOP, I didn't mean to let another cat out of the bag.
